title: Considerations Before Taking B-Cell Therapy

content: You've heard of B-cell therapy -- and might even know someone who was prescribed the treatment for relapsing remitting multiple sclerosis -- and now you're wondering if these biologics might be the right medication to manage the bouts of fatigue, numbness, vision issues, and other symptoms of the disease. B cells are an essential part of the immune system; their role is to create antibodies that protect against infection. In relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS), B cells enter the brain and make antibodies that target the myelin, the protective coating around the nerves. B cells also activate T cells that join the attack on the myelin. It creates the relapsing-remitting symptoms that are the hallmarks of RRMS.

sections.heading: What Is B-cell Therapy?
content: B-cell therapy has emerged as an important treatment option for RRMS. The treatment, also called B-cell-depleting monoclonal antibodies, targets B cells that attack the immune cells while preserving protective antibodies. Studies have shown that B-cell therapy is "highly effective" against RRMS and have been shown to reduce relapses and slow disease progression. But additional research found that B-cell depletion therapy doesn't resolve chronic active lesions in MS, and those lesions play a major role in the clinical progression of MS. It means that your MS-related disability may get worse even if the number of relapses goes down while you receive B-cell therapy.

sections.heading: Which Medications Are Used for B-cell Therapy?
content: There are several B-cell therapies used to treat multiple sclerosis. Ocrelizumab (Ocrevus), ofatumumab (Kesimpta) and ublituximab-xiiy (Briumvi) are approved by the FDA, while rituximab (Rituxan), which is often used to treat autoimmune disorders, is used "off label" to treat MS.

sections.heading: Questions to Ask About B-cell Therapy
content: Although there is a lot of research showing that B-cell therapy is effective for treating RRMS, there are some important things to consider before deciding if it's the right treatment for you. Ask your doctor these seven questions: Is B-cell therapy right for me? B-cell therapy is not right for everyone. You shouldn't receive the treatment if you have an active hepatitis B infection. Talk to your doctor if you are pregnant or planning to become pregnant. B-cell therapy manufacturers recommend people of child-bearing age take birth control while taking B-cell therapy and for at least 6 months after stopping treatment.

sections.heading: How does treatment work?
content: There are two ways to receive B-cell therapies: IV infusion or subcutaneous injection. Ocrelizumab is an infusion therapy that is given through an IV in an infusion center or medical clinic. In the first year, you'll receive three infusions. The first two infusions will be given 2 weeks apart; the third infusion will be given 6 months later. Rituximab and ublituximab-xiiy are also given by IV infusion. Rituximab is given once every 6 months, and ublituximab-xiiy includes an initial round of two infusions given 2 weeks apart with follow-up infusions every 24 weeks. Ofatumumab is a once-a-month injection with a prefilled auto-injector pen that can be done at home. What are the side effects? It's important to be aware of potential side effects from B-cell therapy. Some of the common symptoms include: Injection site reactions Itchy skin or rash Hives Fatigue Coughing, wheezing, trouble breathing Fever Nausea Headache Dizziness Fast heartbeat Increased risk of infection, including bacterial, fungal, or viral infections

sections.heading: How much does B-cell therapy cost?
content: There is also the potential to develop progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy or PML, a rare but serious brain infection that can result in disability or death. Your doctor will monitor you for symptoms like confusion, dizziness, loss of balance, trouble walking or talking, weakness, or vision problems that could be a sign of PML. You should report any of these symptoms to your doctor immediately. The annual cost for the medications are: Ublituximab-xiiy: $59,000 per year Rituximab: $58,304 per year Ofatumumab: $35,000 in the first year and $28,000 in the second year (and beyond) Ocrelizumab: $32,600 per year Several factors affect how much you'll pay for B-cell therapy, including your insurance coverage, co-pays, and eligibility for patient assistance programs. What happens if I stop treatment? Researchers have been studying how B cells react after treatment stops, and it appears that the cells were more prone to making proteins that triggered inflammation and showed higher production of two proteins that were linked with B-cell growth and activation.

sections.heading: How will you determine if the treatment works?
content: Your doctor will perform regular blood tests to monitor a type of B cell known as a memory B cell to ensure the medication is working like it should and use that information to tailor the frequency of your infusions or injections. Could my race impact how well B-cell therapy works? New research looked at the impact of race on the effectiveness of B-cell therapy for MS and made some surprising findings: In the 6 to 12 months following infusion treatment, Black patients had more B cells reappear in their blood than White patients, which could be a result of different immune responses to the treatment. Although B cells play a major role in the pathology of MS and B-cell therapy can be an important treatment, it's important to weigh the pros and cons and talk to your doctor to decide if it's the right medication for you.
